introduction.p:
The previous section introduced vectors and linear combinations and demonstrated how they provide a way to think about linear systems geometrically. In particular, we saw that the vector \bvec is a linear combination of the vectors \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n precisely when the linear system corresponding to the augmented matrix
\left[\begin{array}{rrrr|r} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \cdots \amp \vvec_n \amp \bvec \end{array}\right]
is consistent.
Our goal in this section is to introduce matrix multiplication, another algebraic operation that deepens the connection between linear systems and linear combinations.

subsection.title: Scalar multiplication and addition of matrices
subsection.p:
matrix, shape We first thought of a matrix as a rectangular array of numbers. If we say that the shape of a matrix is m\times n, we mean that it has m rows and n columns. For instance, the shape of the matrix below is 3\times4:
\left[ \begin{array}{rrrr} 0 \amp 4 \amp -3 \amp 1 \\ 3 \amp -1 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ 2 \amp 0 \amp -1 \amp 1 \\ \end{array} \right] .

We may also think of the columns of a matrix as a set of vectors. For instance, the matrix above may be represented as
\left[ \begin{array}{rrrr} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \vvec_3 \amp \vvec_4 \end{array} \right]
where
\vvec_1=\left[\begin{array}{r}0\\3\\2\\ \end{array}\right], \vvec_2=\left[\begin{array}{r}4\\-1\\0\\ \end{array}\right], \vvec_3=\left[\begin{array}{r}-3\\2\\-1\\ \end{array}\right], \vvec_4=\left[\begin{array}{r}1\\0\\1\\ \end{array}\right] . In this way, we see that the 3\times 4 matrix is equivalent to an ordered set of 4 vectors in \real^3.

subsection.p: As this preview activity shows, the operations of scalar multiplication and addition of matrices are natural extensions of their vector counterparts. Some care, however, is required when adding matrices. Since we need the same number of vectors to add and since those vectors must be of the same dimension, two matrices must have the same shape if we wish to form their sum.

subsection.title: Matrix-vector multiplication and linear combinations
subsection.p: A more important operation will be matrix multiplication as it allows us to compactly express linear systems. We now introduce the product of a matrix and a vector with an example.

statement.p: Because A has two columns, we need two weights to form a linear combination of those columns, which means that \xvec must have two components. In other words, the number of columns of A must equal the dimension of the vector \xvec.
Similarly, the columns of A are 3-dimensional so any linear combination of them is 3-dimensional as well. Therefore, A\xvec will be 3-dimensional.
We then see that if A is a 3\times2 matrix, \xvec must be a 2-dimensional vector and A\xvec will be 3-dimensional.

subsection.p: More generally, we have the following definition.

statement.p:
The product of a matrix A by a vector \xvec will be the linear combination of the columns of A using the components of \xvec as weights. More specifically, if
A=\left[\begin{array}{rrrr} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \ldots \amp \vvec_n \end{array}\right],~~~ \xvec = \left[\begin{array}{r} c_1 \\ c_2 \\ \vdots \\ c_n \end{array}\right],
then
A\xvec = c_1\vvec_1 + c_2\vvec_2 + \ldots + c_n\vvec_n .
If A is an m\times n matrix, then \xvec must be an n-dimensional vector, and the product A\xvec will be an m-dimensional vector.

subsection.p:
Multiplication of a matrix A and a vector is defined as a linear combination of the columns of A. However, there is a shortcut for computing such a product. Let's look at our previous example and focus on the first row of the product.
\left[\begin{array}{rr} -2 \amp 3 \\ 0 \amp 2 \\ 3 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{r} 2 \\ 3 \\ \end{array}\right] = 2 \left[\begin{array}{r} -2 \\ * \\ * \\ \end{array}\right] + 3 \left[\begin{array}{r} 3 \\ * \\ * \\ \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{c} 2(-2)+3(3) \\ * \\ * \\ \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{r} 5 \\ * \\ * \\ \end{array}\right] .

To find the first component of the product, we consider the first row of the matrix. We then multiply the first entry in that row by the first component of the vector, the second entry by the second component of the vector, and so on, and add the results. In this way, we see that the third component of the product would be obtained from the third row of the matrix by computing 2(3) + 3(1) = 9.
You are encouraged to evaluate the product of the previous activity using this shortcut and compare the result to what you found while completing that activity.

subsection.title: Matrix-vector multiplication and linear systems
subsection.p: So far, we have begun with a matrix A and a vector \xvec and formed their product A\xvec = \bvec. We would now like to turn this around: beginning with a matrix A and a vector \bvec, we will ask if we can find a vector \xvec such that A\xvec = \bvec. This will naturally lead back to linear systems.

To see the connection between the matrix equation A\xvec = \bvec and linear systems, let's write the matrix A in terms of its columns \vvec_i and \xvec in terms of its components.
A = \left[ \begin{array}{rrrr} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \ldots \vvec_n \end{array} \right], \xvec = \left[ \begin{array}{c} c_1 \\ c_2 \\ \vdots \\ c_n \\ \end{array} \right] .

We know that the matrix product A\xvec forms a linear combination of the columns of A. Therefore, the equation A\xvec = \bvec is merely a compact way of writing the equation for the weights c_i:
c_1\vvec_1 + c_2\vvec_2 + \ldots + c_n\vvec_n = \bvec . We have seen this equation before: Remember that says that the solutions of this equation are the same as the solutions to the linear system whose augmented matrix is
\left[\begin{array}{rrrr|r} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \ldots \amp \vvec_n \amp \bvec \end{array}\right] .
This gives us three different ways of looking at the same solution space.

statement.p:
If A=\left[\begin{array}{rrrr} \vvec_1\amp\vvec_2\amp\ldots\vvec_n \end{array}\right] and \xvec=\left[ \begin{array}{c} x_1 \\ x_2 \\ \vdots \\ x_n \\ \end{array}\right] , then the following statements are equivalent.
The vector \xvec satisfies the equation A\xvec = \bvec .
The vector \bvec is a linear combination of the columns of A with weights x_j:
x_1\vvec_1 + x_2\vvec_2 + \ldots + x_n\vvec_n = \bvec .
The components of \xvec form a solution to the linear system corresponding to the augmented matrix
\left[\begin{array}{rrrr|r} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \cdots \amp \vvec_n \amp \bvec \end{array}\right]\text{.}

subsection.p:
When the matrix A = \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} \vvec_1\amp\vvec_2\amp\cdots\amp\vvec_n\end{array}\right], we will frequently write
\left[\begin{array}{rrrr|r} \vvec_1\amp\vvec_2\amp\cdots\amp\vvec_n\amp\bvec\end{array}\right] = \left[ \begin{array}{r|r} A \amp \bvec \end{array}\right]
and say that the matrix A is augmented by the vector \bvec.

The equation A\xvec = \bvec gives a notationally compact way to write a linear system. Moreover, this notation will allow us to focus on important features of the system that determine its solution space.

statement.p:
We will describe the solution space of the equation
\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 2 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ 4 \amp -1 \amp 6 \\ 1 \amp 3 \amp -5 \\ \end{array}\right] \xvec = \left[\begin{array}{r} 0 \\ -5 \\ 15 \end{array}\right].

By , this equation may be equivalently expressed as
x_1\left[\begin{array}{r}2\\4\\1\end{array}\right] + x_2\left[\begin{array}{r}0\\-1\\3\end{array}\right]+ x_3\left[\begin{array}{r}2\\6\\-5\end{array}\right]= \left[\begin{array}{r}0\\-5\\15\end{array}\right] , which is the linear system corresponding to the augmented matrix
\left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 2 \amp 0 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ 4 \amp -1 \amp 6 \amp -5 \\ 1 \amp 3 \amp -5 \amp 15 \\ \end{array} \right] . The reduced row echelon form of the augmented matrix is
\left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 2 \amp 0 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ 4 \amp -1 \amp 6 \amp -5 \\ 1 \amp 3 \amp -5 \amp 15 \\ \end{array} \right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -2 \amp 5 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array} \right],
which corresponds to the linear system
\begin{alignedat}{4} x_1 \amp \amp \amp {}+{} \amp x_3 \amp {}={} \amp 0 \\ \amp \amp x_2 \amp {}-{} \amp 2x_3 \amp {}={} \amp 5. \\ \end{alignedat}
The variable x_3 is free so we may write the solution space parametrically as
\begin{aligned} x_1 \amp {}={} -x_3 \\ x_2 \amp {}={} 5+2x_3. \\ \end{aligned}

Since we originally asked to describe the solutions to the equation A\xvec = \bvec, we will express the solution in terms of the vector \xvec:
\xvec =\left[ \begin{array}{r} x_1 \\ x_2 \\ x_3 \end{array} \right] = \left[ \begin{array}{r} -x_3 \\ 5 + 2x_3 \\ x_3 \end{array} \right] =\left[\begin{array}{r}0\\5\\0\end{array}\right] +x_3\left[\begin{array}{r}-1\\2\\1\end{array}\right]
As before, we call this a parametric description of the solution space.

This shows that the solutions \xvec may be written in the form \vvec + x_3\wvec, for appropriate vectors \vvec and \wvec. Geometrically, the solution space is a line in \real^3 through \vvec moving parallel to \wvec.

subsection.title: Matrix-matrix products
subsection.p: In this section, we have developed some algebraic operations on matrices with the aim of simplifying our description of linear systems. We now introduce a final operation, the product of two matrices, that will become important when we study linear transformations in .

statement.p:
Given matrices A and B, we form their product AB by first writing B in terms of its columns
B = \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \cdots \amp \vvec_p \end{array}\right]
and then defining
AB = \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} A\vvec_1 \amp A\vvec_2 \amp \cdots \amp A\vvec_p \end{array}\right].

Given the matrices
A = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 4 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ -3 \amp 4 \\ 2 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right],~~~ B = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} -2 \amp 3 \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp -2 \\ \end{array}\right] , we have
AB = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} A \twovec{-2}{1} \amp A \twovec{3}{2} \amp A \twovec{0}{-2} \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} -6 \amp 16 \amp -4 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp -2 \\ 10 \amp -1 \amp -8 \\ -4 \amp 6 \amp 0 \end{array}\right] .

It is important to note that we can only multiply matrices if the shapes of the matrices are compatible. More specifically, when constructing the product AB, the matrix A multiplies the columns of B. Therefore, the number of columns of A must equal the number of rows of B. When this condition is met, the number of rows of AB is the number of rows of A, and the number of columns of AB is the number of columns of B.

subsection.p: This activity demonstrated some general properties about products of matrices, which mirror some properties about operations with real numbers.

assemblage.title: Properties of Matrix-matrix Multiplication
assemblage.p:
If A, B, and C are matrices such that the following operations are defined, it follows that
Associativity:
A(BC) = (AB)C.
Distributivity:
A(B+C) = AB+AC.
(A+B)C = AC+BC.

subsection.p: At the same time, there are a few properties that hold for real numbers that do not hold for matrices.

assemblage.title: Caution
assemblage.p:
The following properties hold for real numbers but not for matrices.
Commutativity:
It is not generally true that AB = BA.
Cancellation:
It is not generally true that AB = AC implies that B = C.
Zero divisors:
It is not generally true that AB = 0 implies that either A=0 or B=0.

subsection.title: Summary
subsection.p:
In this section, we have found an especially simple way to express linear systems using matrix multiplication.
If A is an m\times n matrix and \xvec an n-dimensional vector, then A\xvec is the linear combination of the columns of A using the components of \xvec as weights. The vector A\xvec is m-dimensional.
The solution space to the equation A\xvec = \bvec is the same as the solution space to the linear system corresponding to the augmented matrix \left[ \begin{array}{r|r} A \amp \bvec \end{array}\right].
If A is an m\times n matrix and B is an n\times p matrix, we can form the product AB, which is an m\times p matrix whose columns are the products of A and the columns of B.
